subject: Entrepreneurship
title: How Venture Capital Actually Works
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on How Venture Capital Actually Works.

hook.text: A VC fund raises $100M from pension funds, then bets it on 30 startups hoping one becomes huge.

buildup.text: VCs are professional investors who manage other people's money, called limited partners (LPs).

discovery.text: The math: most investments fail. VCs need one 100x return to make the entire fund profitable.

twist.text: This is why VCs push for massive growth. A $10M company is a failure in their portfolio model.

climax.text: VC is a power-law business. The top 10 deals generate more returns than the other thousands combined.

punchline.text: VCs don't want your startup to succeed. They need it to be enormous.

quiz.question: Why do VCs push startups toward massive growth?
options: Their fund model requires a few enormous wins to offset many losses
They get paid more for larger companies
Larger companies are easier to manage
